title: 115_hr1116
content: The Act may be cited as the "Taking Account of Institutions with Low Operation Risk Act of 2017" or the "TAILOR Act of 2017". It includes regulations appropriate to business models. Each Federal financial institutions regulatory agency must consider the risk profile and business models of institutions, determine the necessity and impact of regulatory actions, and tailor regulations to limit compliance costs and burdens. Each Federal financial institutions regulatory agency must consider the impact of regulatory actions on institutions' ability to serve diverse customer needs, potential conflicts with other directives, and the underlying policy objectives. Notice of Proposed and Final Rulemaking must be disclosed by each agency. The financial institutions regulatory agency must disclose how they have applied certain subsections in all rulemaking notices and final rules. Each agency must report annually to specific congressional committees on actions taken to tailor regulatory actions according to the Act. The head of each Federal financial institution regulatory agency must testify before specific congressional committees on the contents of reports submitted. The Financial Institutions Examination Council must report on regulatory actions to the committees after each report is submitted. The Chairman of the Financial Institutions Examination Council must testify before specific congressional committees on regulatory actions tailored under this Act. The appearance is required after each report submission to explain differential treatment of institutions of diverse charter types. Limited look-back application applies to Federal financial institutions. Each Federal financial institutions regulatory agency must review regulations adopted within seven years before this Act's introduction and apply its requirements. If revisions are needed, they must be completed within three years of the Act's enactment. Definitions in the Act include "Federal financial institutions regulatory agencies." The term "Federal financial institutions regulatory agencies" refers to specific government bodies, including the Office of the Comptroller of the Currency, the Board of Governors of the Federal Reserve System, the Federal Deposit Insurance Corporation, the National Credit Union Administration, and the Bureau of Consumer Financial Protection. Regulatory action encompasses any proposed, interim, or final rule, regulation, guidance, or published interpretation. The Federal Reserve Act is amended to reduce surplus funds of Federal Reserve Banks from $7,500,000,000 to $7,385,714,000, effective June 1, 2018. This amendment was passed by the House of Representatives on March 14, 2018.
